channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Brittney Griner Lands in U.S. After Prisoner Swap
item.description: The homecoming of the American basketball star puts an end to a 10-month ordeal in which she became a bargaining chip between Moscow and Washington.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: China’s Xi, in Saudi Arabia, Continues Re-Emergence From Isolation
item.description: Xi Jinping’s visit to Saudi Arabia highlights Beijing’s renewed bid to compete with Washington after years of preoccupation with the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia welcoming the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, in Riyadh on Thursday.

item.title: She Came Out of Nowhere, and Now No One in France Can Ignore Her
item.description: Sandrine Rousseau is using her talent for grabbing headlines with provocative ideas to shift the focus of the national debate from the themes favored by the far-right to climate change and #MeToo.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: Beijing Braces for Covid Surge After China Lifts Pandemic Curbs
item.description: Residents lined up at hospitals and pharmacies, seeking help for fevers and buying at-home tests after the government’s decision to ease its “zero Covid” policy.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Workers removing a tent at a residential community in Beijing that lifted a lockdown on Friday.

item.title: Russia Cheers Viktor Bout’s Release as a Kremlin Victory
item.description: To the West, he is a criminal with blood on his hands, a global weapons merchant — but Russia portrays Mr. Bout as a victim of American injustice.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: Viktor Bout arriving at a criminal court in Bangkok in 2010. He was later extradited to the United States to stand trial.

item.title: Fringe Group Suspected in German Plot Got a Lift From QAnon
item.description: The Reichsbürger movement accused of plotting to overthrow Germany’s government picked up momentum from conspiracy theories that grew during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Erika Solomon
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Police officers outside a residence they raided on Wednesday to halt what the authorities said was a plan to storm the German Capitol and execute the chancellor.

item.title: What to Know About the Political Turmoil in Peru
item.description: An impeachment vote, an arrest, a new president. A day of political drama presented another challenge for the South American democracy.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Marco Garro for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police fired tear gas to disperse crowds of supporters of Pedro Castillo, now Peru’s former president, after he was arrested on Wednesday.

item.title: UK Government Backs Bill to Criminalize Street Harassment
item.description: The measure targets behavior like catcalling or persistent staring with prison sentences of up to two years, in the hopes that more people will report such occurrences.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers patrolling along the Thames in London. The issue of violence against women has received heightened attention in Britain since the 2021 killing of Sarah Everard.

item.title: France to Make Condoms Free for Young People
item.description: The new policy, which will take effect in January, is part of an effort to counter an increase in sexually transmitted diseases in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: French health authorities say that sexually transmitted infections have been on the rise as a result of a decline in the use of prevention methods.

item.title: China to Cooperate With Gulf Nations on Nuclear Energy and Space, Xi Says
item.description: The Chinese president, Xi Jinping, says that he is eager to work with the Middle Eastern countries, longstanding U.S. allies, in a series of sensitive fields.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Saudi Press Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, fourth from left, met with Gulf leaders in the Saudi capital, Riyadh, on Friday.

item.title: Bangladesh Arrests Opposition Leaders as Crackdown Intensifies
item.description: Tensions boiled over this week as opposition supporters descended on the capital ahead of a major demonstration against the government of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: The police clashed with supporters of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party at the party's central office in Dhaka on Thursday.

item.title: News Analysis: In Brittney Griner Deal, Putin Used Pain, a Familiar Lever
item.description: By seizing the basketball star, the Russian president made things so painful for the U.S. that it capitulated and turned over a convicted arms dealer. Can the same tactic work in the war in Ukraine?
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: The Russian arms dealer Viktor Bout in a temporary cell in Bangkok, Thailand, after his arrest there in 2010.

item.title: Iran Conducts First Known Execution of Prisoner Tied to Nationwide Protests
item.description: Mohsen Shekari, 23, had been sentenced to death on accusations of blocking a street in Tehran and attacking a member of the Basij militia during a protest.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Mohsen Shekari

item.title: Eric Allison, Prison Reporter Who Knew the Beat All Too Well, Dies at 79
item.description: A career criminal in England for nearly a half-century, he was hired by The Guardian to report on injustices in prisons — work that led to exposés and honors.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Netanyahu Cabinet Choice Has Criminal Convictions, Delaying a Government
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing bloc won Israel’s general election last month. But several issues, including his cabinet choices, have complicated the forming of his government.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu and Aryeh Deri in 2020. Mr. Netanyahu’s government has been delayed by his wish to change the law to allow Mr. Deri, who has recent fraud convictions, to serve in the cabinet.

item.title: NATO Chief Warns of ‘Full Blown War’ with Russia
item.description: “If things go wrong, they can go horribly wrong,” Jens Stoltenberg said in an interview published on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Jens Stoltenberg, NATO’s secretary general, speaking in Oslo on Thursday.

item.title: When a Prisoner Swap Is a Rorschach-Test
item.description: The scene on the tarmac with Brittney Griner and Viktor Bout didn’t just show a prisoner trade. It told the story of where two rival countries had landed decades after the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:description: A still from a video distributed by Russian state media shows Brittney Griner, in red, and Viktor Bout, holding a yellow envelope, on the tarmac at the Abu Dhabi International Airport on Thursday.

item.title: Viktor Bout Tells Maria Butina the US Is Trying to ‘Destroy’ Russia
item.description: He made the comments in an interview with Maria Butina, the Russian member of Parliament who served a little over a year in U.S. prisons.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Viktor Bout at a criminal court in Bangkok in 2010. The freed Russian arms dealer returned home to a warm welcome in Moscow.

item.title: Inside the Prisoner Swap That Freed Brittney Griner
item.description: U.S. officials say Moscow had been pushing for the release of a Russian assassin being held in Germany before finally agreeing to release Ms. Griner for Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, the American basketball star imprisoned in Russia on drug charges, arrived in San Antonio on Friday.

item.title: Turkey Is Strengthening Its Energy Ties With Russia
item.description: As Moscow seeks new customers for oil, gas and coal, Ankara is a willing buyer as it promotes plans as a regional trading hub.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is using the energy crisis to advance a longstanding dream of the Turks to become a major energy hub.

item.title: What to Know About the Two Americans Still Detained in Russia
item.description: The State Department has urged U.S. citizens not to travel to Russia and, if they are in the country, to ‘leave immediately.’
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sofia Sandurskaya/Moscow News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Paul Whelan in Moscow in 2020.

item.title: They’re Taking Jigsaw Puzzles to Infinity and Beyond
item.description: In upstate New York, two algorithmic artists make wooden puzzles inspired by natural forms.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: After Release, Brittney Griner Faces Reintegration
item.description: With her prison ordeal over, Brittney Griner will now face the challenge of transitioning back into life at home.
item.dc:creator: Erin Mendell
item.media:description: Brittney Griner appearing in court in October via video link from the detention center in Russia where she was being held.

item.title: Russia Finds War Critic Ilya Yashin Guilty of ‘Spreading False Information’
item.description: Ilya Yashin, who pleaded not guilty, is among the highest-profile opposition politicians remaining in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Ilya Yashin, a Russian opposition politician, in a glass cubicle in a Moscow court on Friday.

item.title: Glimpses of Democracy
item.description: Dissent carries power even in repressive, authoritarian states.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Iranian demonstrators in the streets of Tehran in September.

item.title: With Brittney Griner’s Release, Anxiety Turns to Relief
item.description: Supporters of the W.N.B.A. star had watched with dismay as her situation appeared to worsen over the summer. Now they are celebrating her release.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman, Ben Shpigel, Jonathan Ellis and Talya Minsberg
item.media:description: A video screen at Thursday’s N.B.A. basketball game between the Miami Heat and the Los Angeles Clippers in Miami.

item.title: Qatar Extends Its Natural Gas Dominance at Russia’s Expense
item.description: As its influence grows, the country is poised to become a big energy supplier to Europe, which has turned away from Russia after its invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The liquid natural gas facility in Ras Laffan, Qatar. The country is becoming an indispensable energy supplier with vast reserves and very low costs.

item.title: New Zealand on a Plate
item.description: Why Aotearoa is spectacularly situated to offer some of the world’s most interesting, varied, delicious food.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mark Coote for The New York Times
item.media:description: The tuna carpaccio, with avocado, black vinegar and furikake at the Soul Bar and Bistro in Auckland.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: The American basketball star Brittney Griner was freed in a prisoner swap with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A video from Russian state media showed the prisoner swap involving Brittney Griner, left, and Viktor Bout, 2nd right, at a United Arab Emirates airport.

item.title: Day 9: The Magic of Less ‘Holiday Magic’
item.description: Some people respond to the stress of the season by adopting a Marie Kondo approach: relinquishing the rituals that no longer bring them joy.
item.dc:creator: Susan Shain

item.title: Brittney Griner Will Land at an Army Hospital in San Antonio
item.description: The hospital treats both civilians and military personnel who have survived torture or other trauma.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Brooke Army Medical Center has long been a place to send patients who need to be debriefed or require sensitive medical care.

item.title: Key Partner in Covax Will Stop Giving Free Vaccines to Middle-Income Nations
item.description: Many of the poorest countries will continue to get free Covid shots, but global demand for them has plummeted, driving a shift away from the goal of broad coverage.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Malou Kutey receiving a Covid vaccine in Juba, South Sudan, that was donated by the United States via the Covax program in 2021.

item.title: Who Is Dina Boluarte, Peru’s New and First Woman President?
item.description: Ms. Boluarte, the country’s first woman president, ascended to power suddenly, after her predecessor was arrested. She takes office as corruption and discontent test democracies across Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz, Genevieve Glatsky and Mitra Taj
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Russian State Media Releases Video of Brittney Griner and Viktor Bout Swap
item.description: The images, verified by The New York Times, show Ms. Griner being traded for the arms dealer Viktor Bout on the tarmac at Al Bateen Executive Airport in Abu Dhabi.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph and Kaly Soto

item.title: The Villain So Far in ‘Harry & Meghan’? Not the Royal Family.
item.description: Harry and Meghan focused their ire in their Netflix documentary on the tabloids they say have hounded them out of remorseless greed and scarcely concealed racism.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prince Harry, center, and his wife, Meghan Markle, attending a service for Queen Elizabeth II in June.

item.title: More Americans Are Being ‘Wrongfully Detained’ and Held Abroad
item.description: A State Department official said over the summer that there were between 40 and 50 Americans being wrongfully detained by foreign governments.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cooper
item.media:description: Brittney Griner speaking with her lawyers before a hearing in July. The number of American citizens unjustly detained by foreign governments has risen sharply over the past two decades.

item.title: American Given 8-Month Suspended Sentence in Traffic Death of British Teen
item.description: Anne Sacoolas, a U.S. government employee, had fled England after hitting motorcyclist Harry Dunn, 19, with her car. His parents, who fought for three years to bring her to justice, said, “Harry, we done it.”
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A roadside memorial in 2019 near where Harry Dunn was killed.

item.title: Johnny Johnson, the Last World War II ‘Dambuster,’ Dies at 101
item.description: With the Royal Air Force, he took part in a morale-boosting strike on Nazi Germany’s industrial heartland, breaching dams and unleashing devastating floods.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.media:credit: Getty Images, via Imperial War Museums
item.media:description: In a photo taken in England in July 1943, weeks after their audacious raid into the heart of Germany, Mr. Johnson, left, posed with fellow members of the 617 Squadron, who became known as the Dambusters. The others were, in the foreground from left, Pilot Officer Donald MacLean, navigator; Flight Lt. Joe McCarthy, pilot (an American); and Sgt. Leonard Eaton, gunner. In the rear were, from left, Sgt. Ronald Batson, gunner; and Sgt. William Ratcliffe, engineer.

item.title: What Drove the Creation of Working Dog Breeds?
item.description: Genetic variants associated with brain development help distinguish breeds designed for different physical tasks, a new study reports.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: Sheep herding breeds appear to have a high number of genetic variants associated with a neurodevelopmental process known as axon guidance, which ensures that neurons are wired together correctly.

item.title: China and Saudi Arabia Sign Strategic Partnership as Xi Visits Kingdom
item.description: The Chinese leader Xi Jinping’s trip to Saudi Arabia showcases Beijing’s growing ties with the kingdom, a longtime American ally that is seeking greater self-reliance.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Bandar Al-Jaloud/Saudi Royal Palace, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, right, greeted the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Wife Cherelle: ‘Today, My Family Is Whole’
item.description: Cherelle Griner, who had steadily put pressure on the Biden administration not to forget her wife, thanked WNBA players for their support.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Cherelle Griner, Brittney Griner’s wife, speaking at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Fraud Trial of Wirecard’s Ex-CEO, Markus Braun, Begins
item.description: Markus Braun, the founder of the financial technology firm that lost billions, is facing fraud charges with two others.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Markus Braun, the former Wirecard chief facing fraud charges, in court in Munich on Thursday.

item.title: The Covid Pandemic’s Hidden Casualties: Pregnant Women
item.description: Many expectant women have avoided vaccination, unaware that the virus poses great risks to both fetus and mother.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Only 70 percent of women completed the primary vaccination series for Covid before or during pregnancy, and only 14 percent have opted for a booster shot.

item.title: Who Is Viktor Bout, Arms Dealer in Swap for Brittney Griner?
item.description: Viktor Bout has been accused of supplying arms to Al Qaeda, the Taliban and rebels in Rwanda. His exploits helped inspire a 2005 film, “Lord of War,” that starred Nicolas Cage.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Viktor Bout, a notorious Russian arms dealer, arriving at court in Bangkok in 2010. He was extradited and convicted of conspiring to kill Americans.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Release Puts a Spotlight on Paul Whelan
item.description: Paul Whelan, a corporate security executive, was arrested at a Moscow hotel in December 2018. President Biden says his administration is still working on getting him released.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Paul Whelan in a courtroom in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: How Old Are You? South Korea Tries to Simplify What Should Be a Simple Question.
item.description: Three ways of calculating age coexist in South Korea, so lawmakers have passed a law uniting behind the world standard in an attempt to reduce confusion.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: In South Korea’s hierarchical society, age can determine the way one person speaks to another.

item.title: A ‘Stunning’ 1,300-Year-Old Gold Necklace Is Unearthed in England
item.description: The jewelry found in an ancient grave site in Northamptonshire may have belonged to a woman who was an early Christian leader.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: A 1,300-year-old necklace was discovered in the village of Harpole in Northamptonshire, England, in April.

item.title: ChatGPT is Social Media’s Newest Star
item.description: A new chatbot shows rapid advances in artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: An image generator also made by OpenAI produced this when given the prompt “A distributed linguistic superbrain that takes the form of an A.I. chatbot.”

item.title: ‘Zero Covid,’ Once Ubiquitous, Vanishes in China’s Messy Pivot
item.description: As China casts aside many Covid rules, it is also playing down the threat of the virus. The move could help ease the burden on hospitals but comes with its own risks.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien, Chang Che and John Liu
item.category: Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid testing booth in the Lujiazui financial district of Shanghai. While the rest of the world concluded months ago that the coronavirus was becoming less deadly, Beijing has presented the development as fresh news.

item.title: ‘Ebola Could Have Wiped Us All’: Slow Lockdown Haunts Uganda
item.description: The authorities hesitated to impose restrictions in the epicenter of the Ebola outbreak because of residual trauma from the Covid lockdown. Ebola then spread to the capital, killing dozens of Ugandans.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Esther Ruth Mbabazi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ssekiranda Fred and his three remaining children last month at the grave of his 12-year-old son, Ssebiranda Isaiah Victor, who contracted Ebola in Kampala, the capital of Uganda.

item.title: How the Global Spyware Industry Spiraled Out of Control
item.description: The market for commercial spyware — which allows governments to invade mobile phones and vacuum up data — is booming. Even the U.S. government is using it.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

item.title: Inside the Case Against General Salvador Cienfuegos Zepeda
item.description: A Times Magazine-ProPublica investigation reveals how the U.S. painstakingly built a case against a Mexican general suspected of links to organized crime — and then decided to let him go.
item.dc:creator: Tim Golden

item.title: Tiny Vanuatu Uses Its ‘Unimportance’ to Launch Big Climate Ideas
item.description: It wants a top international court to weigh in on whether nations are legally bound to protect against climate risks.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Vanuatu is threatened by rising seas. “We had to learn how to manage our unimportance,” its president said.

item.title: 6 Takeaways From the ‘Harry and Meghan’ Netflix Documentary
item.description: In the first three episodes, the couple describes ongoing harassment from the news media and wanting to continue Princess Diana’s legacy.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: A Surge in Tourists in Restive Kashmir, but ‘No Mental Peace’ for Residents
item.description: Visitors have flocked back to the region — proof, India says, that its imposition of control worked. But people who live there say fear and uncertainty persist.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Showkat Nanda for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the tulip garden in Srinagar, Kashmir, in April. India says more than two million people visited the Kashmir Valley this year.

item.title: Liz Garbus on Making the Harry and Meghan Netflix Series ‘Personal and Raw’
item.description: The documentary series is the most high-profile project from Story Syndicate, a company run by the filmmaker Liz Garbus and her husband, Dan Cogan.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Netflix released “Harry & Meghan,” a docuseries directed by Liz Garbus about Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, on Thursday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A plot to overthrow the government in Germany.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Police escort a person after 25 suspected members and supporters of a far-right group were detained during raids across Germany on Wednesday.

item.title: A Gray Area of Loyalties Splinters a Liberated Ukrainian Town
item.description: “Friends are not friends anymore,’’ said one woman in the town of Sviatohirsk, which remains divided not by trench lines and artillery, but by where people’s allegiances lie: with Moscow or Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: A man, left, wheels a coffin down a street in Sviatohirsk, tasked with reburying a child killed in the shelling whose death was being investigated by police. Suspicions about loyalties have divided the residents of the town.

item.title: Putin Warns Russians of Protracted Ukraine War, But Says He Won’t Call Up Troops
item.description: Vladimir Putin appeared to acknowledge that subduing Russia’s neighbor was taking longer than expected, but said there was no need for another draft now.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mikhail Metzel/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin during a meeting of the Presidential Council for Civil Society and Human Rights, via video conference, in Moscow on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: China Eases Covid Restrictions
item.description: Also, Peru’s president is ousted and Germany arrests 25 people suspected of plotting a coup.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: An elderly couple in Beijing.
